{{use British English|date=August 2017}} {{use DMY dates|date=August 2017}} On 27 August 2017, [[Beachy Head]] and beaches including [[Birling Gap]], in the English county of [[East Sussex]] were evacuated following a suspected chemical leak. Visitors reported ill effects after the appearance of a "mist", and 233 people were treated at Eastbourne General Hospital, initially with a full chemical decontamination.<ref name="independent">{{cite news|first=Rachel|last=Roberts|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/beachy-head-chemical-incident-chlorine-suspected-leak-stinging-bank-holiday-a7915721.html|title=Police investigate suspected 'chemical incident' at Beachy Head after 50 people complain of stinging eyes and throats|publisher=Independent Print Limited|newspaper=The Independent|date=28 August 2017|accessdate=28 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827215804/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/beachy-head-chemical-incident-chlorine-suspected-leak-stinging-bank-holiday-a7915721.html|archivedate=27 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-41070002|title=Birling Gap beach: 150 treated after chemical 'mist'|date=28 August 2017|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827233842/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-41070002|archivedate=27 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Witnesses reported that no matter how many times they washed their eyes, they were stinging and drying up regardless.<ref>{{cite news|title=Beach evacuated as toxic mist blows in|last=Adams|first=Callum|work=The Times|date=28 August 2017|page=7|issue=72313|issn=0140-0460}}</ref>
Whilst it was unclear what the gas actually was, [[chlorine]] was blamed initially. [[East Sussex Fire and Rescue Service]] stated that "due to the symptoms and situation described", the gas was unlikely to be chlorine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/aug/29/investigators-believe-toxic-cloud-on-sussex-coast-came-from-ship|title=Toxic cloud on Sussex coast may have come from ship, say sources|last=Weaver|first=Matthew|date=29 August 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=29 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829185125/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/aug/29/investigators-believe-toxic-cloud-on-sussex-coast-came-from-ship|archivedate=29 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Previous chemical emission clouds have drifted across from industrial units in Northern France, however, the [[Maritime and Coastguard Agency]] (MCA) have stated that in this incident such a scenario was unlikely due to weather models.<ref>{{cite news|title=Birling Gap beach: Shipwreck 'could be to blame for mist'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-41130937|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=BBC News|date=1 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170902005140/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-41130937|archivedate=2 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The MCA said that one line of investigation was a possible leak from a disturbed shipwreck, with the [[SS Mira (UK ship)|SS ''Mira'']], a 3,700-tonne [[World War I|First World War]] armed tanker sunk by a German mine on 11 October 1917, suggested as one potential source. Investigators from the MCA were also looking at some 180 ships that passed through the area on 27 August 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/sep/01/shipwreck-investigated-as-potential-cause-of-sussex-coast-toxic-plume|title=Shipwreck investigated as potential cause of Sussex coast toxic plume|first=Matthew|last=Weaver|date=1 September 2017|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=3 September 2017|work=The Guardian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170903020743/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/sep/01/shipwreck-investigated-as-potential-cause-of-sussex-coast-toxic-plume|archivedate=3 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2018 [[BBC Sussex]] requested police fire ard ambulance logs under a [[Freedom of information in the United Kingdom|freedom of information]] request.<ref name=bbc-birling-gap-chemical-haze-stopped-helicopters>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-45300408|title=Birling Gap chemical haze stopped helicopters flying|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=28 August 2018|accessdate=29 August 2018}}</ref> The [[National Police Air Service]] and [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] were asked to help but said their aircraft could not fly in the circumstances.<ref name=bbc-birling-gap-chemical-haze-stopped-helicopters/> Helicopters could not be used to investigate the haze as it wasn't known if the gas was explosive.<ref name=bbc-birling-gap-chemical-haze-stopped-helicopters/> East Sussex Fire Service used gas detection equipment, but could not detect anything as the cloud had dispersed.<ref name=bbc-birling-gap-chemical-haze-stopped-helicopters/> ==Reaction== [[Caroline Lucas]], the [[Green Party of England and Wales|Green Party]] MP for [[Brighton Pavilion (UK Parliament constituency)|Brighton Pavilion]] called for an urgent inquiry to determine the cause."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/aug/28/sussex-chemical-cloud-unlikely-to-have-come-from-france-say-police|last=Hunt|first=Elle|title=Greens call for urgent inquiry into East Sussex chemical cloud|date=27 August 2017|access-date=28 August 2017|work=The Guardian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170828145152/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/aug/28/sussex-chemical-cloud-unlikely-to-have-come-from-france-say-police|archivedate=28 August 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}

'''The Al Baydha Project''', in rural, [[Hejaz|western Saudi Arabia]], is a [[land restoration]], poverty-alleviation, and heritage preservation program, based on principles of [[permaculture|permacultural]] and [[Hydrology (agriculture)|hydrological]] design. Located roughly 50 kilometers (20 miles) south of [[Mecca]], in [[Makkah Province]], Al Baydha is an area characterized by the rocky, arid, [[foothills]] of the [[Hijaz Mountains]]. [[Bedouin]] tribes are the major residents of this region.<ref>https://permacultureglobal.org/projects/286-al-baydha-project</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://permaculturenews.org/2010/11/18/permaculture-in-mecca/|title=Permaculture in Mecca - The Permaculture Research Institute|date=18 November 2010|publisher=}}</ref>
Founded in 2009, and led by permaculturist Neal Spackman<ref>http://permacultureglobal.org/users/1234-neal-spackman</ref> and Co-Founder Mona Hamdy,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l_8EfVXP1KE|title=In Dialogue with: Mona Hamdy @ NOVUS 2016|first=|last=kharecom|date=23 January 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thnk.org/people-of-thnk/person/mona-hamdy/|title=Mona Hamdy - THNK School of Creative Leadership|publisher=}}</ref> Al Baydha has begun to see practical and [[restoration ecology|ecological]] results ([https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=it4ru0HvrfE shown here]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://permaculturenews.org/2011/01/14/permaculture-at-the-al-baydha-project-in-saudi-arabia-neal-spackman-video-1/|title=Permaculture at the Al-Baydha Project in Saudi Arabia - Neal Spackman, Video 1 - The Permaculture Research Institute|date=14 January 2011|publisher=}}</ref>
Most notably, Al Baydha's emphasis is on creating an economy for the inhabitants of Al Baydha that is socially, culturally, environmentally, and economically sustainable. The project's main objective is to create financial and social independence for the inhabitants by training, educating and employing them in the infrastructure and capacity building activities undertaken by the Al Baydha Project.<ref>http://www.wondros.com/5d/albaydha/</ref>
Al Baydha's environmental goal is the reversal of desertification. This is accomplished largely via [[rainwater harvesting]], through utilization of rock [[terrace (agriculture)|terraces]] and [[gabion]]s (or small [[check dam]]s), as well as catchment of [[surface runoff|runoff]] into [[swale (landform)|swale]] lines. These support [[afforestation]] of [[drought tolerance|drought-resistant]] trees, such as [[date palm]]s, in the [[natural landscape]]. Another focus of the program is on slowing down [[flash flood]]s in the highlands, and, over time, converting them into seasonal streams or [[wadi]]s, as [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fdlI-7HO2vI shown here]. In the long-term future, Al Baydha hopes to transform the region into a [[savanna|savanna ecosystem]], in part, by means of [[assisted natural regeneration]], [[conservation grazing]], and the effects of [[evapotranspiration]] and atmospheric [[moisture recycling]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://permaculturenews.org/2012/11/09/planting-days-are-here-al-baydha-saudi-arabia/|title=Planting Days Are Here! (Al Baydha, Saudi Arabia) - The Permaculture Research Institute|date=9 November 2012|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.permies.com/t/40248/desert/months-growth-swales-Saudi-Arabia|title=20 months of growth on swales in Saudi Arabia: Two rainfalls since 2010 (greening the desert forum at permies)|website=www.permies.com}}</ref>
In 2016, the Al Baydha Project received a commendation from HRH Prince [[Khaled Al Faisal]] for innovative work undertaken by the inhabitants of Al Baydha as a model of national excellence<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qREss_eycV0|title=لقاء الامير خالد الفيصل في برنامج المختصر|publisher=}}</ref> in humanitarianism, sustainability, and innovation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mbc.net/ar/programs/mbc-news/articles/%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88--%D8%B9%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%85%D8%A7-%D9%8A%D8%A8%D9%86%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%86-%D9%82%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AA%D9%87-%D8%A8%D9%86%D9%81%D8%B3%D9%87---%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D9%83%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%A5%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%86%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%B0.html|title=الرئيسية - MBC.net|website=www.mbc.net}}</ref>
A [[Wadi Rum Consultancy|similar project]], overseen by permaculturist [[Geoff Lawton]] (who advised on the design of Al Baydha), has already achieved success in [[Wadi Rum]], in southern [[Jordan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://permaculturenews.org/2014/02/01/desert-oasis-4-years-jordan/|title=From Desert to Oasis in 4 Years|date=1 February 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
For a video demonstration of these hydrological design techniques, with actual footage from the Al Baydha project, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lp1nwt_XmY0 click here].
For a general introduction to the project, presented by Neal Spackman, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L6LmVDujYWY click here].

'''''Astragalus''''' is a large genus of about 4,200 species of [[herb]]s and small [[shrub]]s, belonging to the [[legume]] family [[Fabaceae]] and the [[subfamily]] [[Faboideae]]. It is the [[List of the largest genera of flowering plants|largest genus of plants in terms of described species]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/4135449 |jstor=4135449 |title=History and Concepts of Big Plant Genera |journal=Taxon |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=753–76 |year=2004 |last1=Frodin |first1=David G }}</ref> The genus is native to temperate regions of the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. Common names include '''milkvetch''' (most species), '''[[locoweed]]''' (in North America, some species)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootcellar.us/wildflowers/astrag.htm |title=''Astragalus'' (Locoweed) flowers |publisher=Rootcellar.us |date= |accessdate=2013-07-05}}</ref> and '''goat's-thorn''' (''A. gummifer'', ''A. tragacanthus''). Some pale-flowered [[Vicia|vetches]] are similar in appearance, but vetches are more [[vine]]-like.
==Ecology== ''Astragalus'' species are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of some [[Lepidoptera]] species including many case-bearing moths of the genus ''[[Coleophora]]'': ''[[coleophora cartilaginella|C. cartilaginella]]'', ''[[coleophora colutella|C. colutella]]'', ''[[coleophora euryaula|C. euryaula]]'', and ''[[Coleophora onobrychiella|C. onobrychiella]]'' feed exclusively on ''Astragalus'', ''[[coleophora astragalella|C. astragalella]]'' and ''[[coleophora gallipennella|C. gallipennella]]'' feed exclusively on the species ''[[Astragalus glycyphyllos]]'', and ''[[coleophora hippodromica|C. hippodromica]]'' is limited to ''[[Astragalus gombo]]''.
==Traditional uses== The natural gum [[tragacanth]] is made from several species of ''Astragalus'' occurring in the [[Middle East]], including ''A. adscendens'', ''A. gummifer'', ''[[Astragalus brachycalyx|A. brachycalyx]]'',<ref>[http://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Astragalus+membranaceus ''Astragalus membranaceus'' - Moench]. Plants for a Future.</ref><ref name="GRIN">{{GRIN|id=433295|name=''Astragalus brachycalyx'' Fisch.|accessdate=24 December 2010}}</ref> and ''A. tragacanthus''. Also ''[[Astragalus propinquus]]'' (syn. ''A. membranaceus'') has a history of use as a [[herbal medicine]] used in systems of [[traditional Chinese medicine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/astragalus-000223.htm |title=''Astragalus'' | University of Maryland Medical Center |publisher=Umm.edu |date=2013-05-07 |accessdate=2013-07-05}}</ref> and Persian medicine.<ref>Zargary, A. Medicinal plants. 5th Edition.Tehran: Tehran University Publications 1990; pp. 312–314.</ref> In traditional Chinese medicine A. membranaceus has been used to reinforce [[qi]] and strengthen the superficial resistance, and promote the discharge of pus and the growth of new tissue.<ref name=pmid25083916>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bcp.2014.07.018 |pmid=25083916 |pmc=4212005 |title=Natural product agonists of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ): A review |journal=Biochemical Pharmacology |volume=92 |issue=1 |pages=73–89 |year=2014 |last1=Wang |first1=Limei |last2=Waltenberger |first2=Birgit |last3=Pferschy-Wenzig |first3=Eva-Maria |last4=Blunder |first4=Martina |last5=Liu |first5=Xin |last6=Malainer |first6=Clemens |last7=Blazevic |first7=Tina |last8=Schwaiger |first8=Stefan |last9=Rollinger |first9=Judith M |last10=Heiss |first10=Elke H |last11=Schuster |first11=Daniela |last12=Kopp |first12=Brigitte |last13=Bauer |first13=Rudolf |last14=Stuppner |first14=Hermann |last15=Dirsch |first15=Verena M |last16=Atanasov |first16=Atanas G }}</ref>
==Research== Biotechnology firms are working on deriving a [[telomerase]] activator from ''Astragalus''. The chemical constituent [[cycloastragenol]] (also called TAT2) is being studied to help combat [[HIV]], as well as infections associated with chronic diseases or aging,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2009/01/01/Herbal_chemical_helps_combat_HIV/UPI-75921230846928/ |title=Herbal chemical helps combat HIV |date=January 1, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2011 |publisher=United Press International}}</ref> the [[National Institutes of Health]] states: "The evidence for using astragalus for any health condition is limited. High-quality clinical trials (studies in people) are generally lacking. There is some preliminary evidence to suggest that astragalus, either alone or in combination with other herbs, may have potential benefits for the immune system, heart, and liver, and as an adjunctive therapy for cancer".<ref name=NCCAM>[http://nccih.nih.gov/health/astragalus/ Astragalus], [[NCCAM]].</ref>
Research at the UCLA AIDS Institute focused on the function of cycloastragenol in the aging process of immune cells, and its effects on the cells' response to viral infections. It appears to increase the production of [[telomerase]], an enzyme that mediates the replacement of short bits of DNA known as [[telomere]]s, which play a key role in cell replication, including in cancer processes.<ref name=pmid18981163>{{cite journal |doi=10.4049/jimmunol.181.10.7400 |pmid=18981163 |pmc=2682219 |title=Telomerase-Based Pharmacologic Enhancement of Antiviral Function of Human CD8+ T Lymphocytes |journal=The Journal of Immunology |volume=181 |issue=10 |pages=7400–6 |year=2008 |last1=Fauce |first1=S. R |last2=Jamieson |first2=B. D |last3=Chin |first3=A. C |last4=Mitsuyasu |first4=R. T |last5=Parish |first5=S. T |last6=Ng |first6=H. L |last7=Ramirez Kitchen |first7=C. M |last8=Yang |first8=O. O |last9=Harley |first9=C. B |last10=Effros |first10=R. B }}</ref>
==Supplement use== Extracts of ''[[Astragalus propinquus]]'' ( syn. ''A. membranaceus'') are marketed as life-prolonging extracts for human use. A proprietary extract of the dried root of ''A. membranaceus'', called [[TA-65]], "was associated with a significant age-reversal effect in the immune system, in that it led to declines in the percentage of senescent cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells after six to twelve months of use".<ref name=pmid20822369>{{cite journal |doi=10.1089/rej.2010.1085 |pmid=20822369 |pmc=3045570 |title=A Natural Product Telomerase Activator As Part of a Health Maintenance Program |journal=Rejuvenation Research |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=45–56 |year=2011 |last1=Harley |first1=Calvin B |last2=Liu |first2=Weimin |last3=Blasco |first3=Maria |last4=Vera |first4=Elsa |last5=Andrews |first5=William H |last6=Briggs |first6=Laura A |last7=Raffaele |first7=Joseph M }}</ref> There are mixed data regarding ''Astragalus'', its effects on telomerase, and cancer. For example, although 80% of cancer cells utilize telomerase for their proliferation—a factor that might theoretically be exacerbated by ''Astragalus''—the shortening of telomeres (resulting from such factors as stress and aging and possible contributors to malignancy) might also be mitigated by ''Astragalus''. Thus, short telomeres result in chromosome instability, and the potential for telomere lengthening as a protection against cancer is possible.<ref>{{cite book |doi=10.1007/978-1-60327-879-9_7 |chapter=Role of Telomeres and Telomerase in Cancer |title=Telomeres and Telomerase in Cancer |pages=171–80 |year=2009 |last1=Hiyama |first1=Keiko |last2=Hiyama |first2=Eiso |last3=Tanimoto |first3=Keiji |last4=Nishiyama |first4=Masahiko |isbn=978-1-60327-306-0 }}</ref> Additionally, scientists recently reported that cancer cells may proliferate precisely because of the lack of differentiation occurring via damaged or shortened telomere length. They propose that "forced" elongation of telomeres promotes the differentiation of cancer cells, probably reducing malignancy, which is strongly associated with a loss of cell differentiation.
==Side effects and toxicology== ''Astragalus'' may interact with medications that suppress the [[immune system]], such as [[cyclophosphamide]].<ref name=NCCAM/> It may also affect [[blood sugar]] levels and [[blood pressure]].<ref name=NCCAM/> Some ''Astragalus'' species can be toxic. For example, several species native to North America contain the [[alkaloid]] [[swainsonine]], which may cause "locoism" in livestock.<ref name=NCCAM/> The toxicity of ''Astragalus'' taxa varies.<ref name=arpt>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1573(199709)11:6<411::AID-PTR132>3.0.CO;2-6 |title=A review of the pharmacology and toxicology of ''Astragalus'' |journal=Phytotherapy Research |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=411–8 |year=1997 |last1=Rios |first1=J. L |last2=Waterman |first2=P. G }}</ref>
==Ornamental use== Several species, including ''A. alpinus'' (bluish-purple flowers), ''A. hypoglottis'' (purple flowers), and ''A. lotoides'', are grown as [[ornamental plant]]s in gardens.

A '''backwater valve''' is a [[backflow prevention device]] used to prevent outbound water through a dwelling's drain pipes from re-entering -- "[[Backflow|back flowing]]"—into a home. The valve contains a flap that allows water to exit the home, but closes to prevent the back flow into the home.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.ca/residents/Sewers-Flooding/Basement-Flooding-Causes/Pages/Backwater-Valve.aspx|title=Backwater Valve|website=www.london.ca|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref>
Backwater valves commonly activate when a city's sewer lines are unable to handle a large amount of falling precipitation; this puts homes that are tied into the storm lines at risk of having water back flow into them.<ref>{{cite web|title=What Is A Backwater Valve?|url=http://www.absolutedp.com/2016/what-is-a-backwater-valve|publisher=Absolute Draining & Plumbing|accessdate=6 November 2016}}</ref>
There is a big difference between backwater valves and backflow preventers:
* A backwater valve prevents raw [[sewage]] from backing up into your home through your [[toilet]]s, [[shower]]s, etc. * A [[backflow preventer]] deals with protecting a potable water source from being contaminated by a reverse flow of foul water (ex: isolating your toilet's flush cistern and water supply from the toilet bowl water itself).
<ref>[http://drpipe.ca/how-to-choose-the-right-backwater-valve/]</ref>

'''Bromelain''' is an [[enzyme]] extract derived from the [[plant stem|stem]]s of [[pineapple]]s, although it exists in all parts of the fresh plant and fruit. The extract has a history of [[folk medicine]] use. As a culinary ingredient, it may be used as a [[meat tenderizer]].
The term "bromelain" may refer to either of two [[protease]] [[enzyme]]s extracted from the plants of the family [[Bromeliaceae]], or it may refer to a combination of those enzymes along with other compounds produced in an extract.
Although tested in a variety of [[folk medicine]] and research models for its possible efficacy against diseases, the only approved [[clinical significance|clinical application]] for bromelain was issued in 2012 by the [[European Medicines Agency]] for a [[topical medication]] called ''[[NexoBrid]]'' used to remove dead tissue in severe skin [[burn]]s.<ref name=nexobrid/>
==Extract components== {{Infobox enzyme | Name = Stem bromelain | EC_number = 3.4.22.32 | CAS_number = 37189-34-7 | IUBMB_EC_number = 3/4/22/32 | GO_code = | image = | width = | caption = }} {{Infobox enzyme | Name = Fruit bromelain | EC_number = 3.4.22.33 | CAS_number = 9001-00-7 | IUBMB_EC_number = 3/4/22/33 | GO_code = | image = | width = | caption = }} Bromelain extract is a mixture of protein-digesting (proteolytic) enzymes and several other substances in smaller quantities. The proteolytic enzymes are [[sulfhydryl]] proteases; a free sulfhydryl group of a [[cysteine]] [[amino acid]] [[side chain]] is required for function. The two main enzymes are:
* [[Stem bromelain]] – {{EC number|3.4.22.32}} * [[Fruit bromelain]] – {{EC number|3.4.22.33}}
==History== Pineapples have a long tradition as a medicinal plant among the natives of South and Central America. The first isolation of bromelain was recorded by the Venezuelan chemist Vicente Marcano in 1891 by [[fermentation in food processing|fermenting]] the fruit of pineapple.<ref>{{cite web| title=Vicente Marcano (in Spanish) Quote from Google translate: "New theory about the phenomenon of fermentation": "See also the bromeliad (for Annana Bromelia L.) pineapple, which is responsible for many phenomena of fermentation of the fruit. This finding, while not making Marcano, was actually made by him, as later confirmed by Dr. RH Chittenden, of Yale University, who argues that "the bromeliad was discovered by a Venezuelan scholar named Vicente Marcano."| url=http://www.pdvsa.com/lexico/pioneros/marcano.htm| date=1997| publisher=Pioneers of Venezuela, PDVSA-Intevep| access-date=2007-03-04| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070330052133/http://www.pdvsa.com/lexico/pioneros/marcano.htm| archive-date=2007-03-30| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref> In 1892, [[Russell Henry Chittenden]], assisted by [[Elliott P. Joslin]] and Frank Sherman Meara, investigated the matter more completely,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chittenden | first1 = RH | first2 = Elliott P | last2 = Joslin | first3 = Frank Sherman | last3 = Meara | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VtNVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA281 | title = On the ferments contained in the juice of the pineapple (''Ananassa sativa''): together with some observations on the composition and proteolytic action of the juice|journal=Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences|year=1892|volume=8|pages=281–308}}</ref> and called it 'bromelin'. Later, the term 'bromelain' was introduced and originally applied to any [[protease]] from any member of the plant family [[Bromeliaceae]].
==Sources== Bromelain is present in all parts of the pineapple plant (''Ananas'' sp.),<ref name="pmid24965557"/> but the stem is the most common commercial source,<ref name="pmid24965557"/><ref name=fbp/> presumably because usable quantities are readily [[extract]]able after the fruit has been harvested.<ref name="pmid24965557"/>
==Production== Produced mainly in parts of the world where pineapples are grown, such as [[Thailand]] or [[Malaysia]], bromelain is [[extraction (chemistry)|extracted]] from the peel, stem, leaves or waste of the pineapple plant after processing the fruit for juice or other purposes.<ref name="pmid24965557">{{cite journal | vauthors = Arshad ZI, Amid A, Yusof F, Jaswir I, Ahmad K, Loke SP | title = Bromelain: an overview of industrial application and purification strategies | journal = Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 98 | issue = 17 | pages = 7283–97 | date = September 2014 | pmid = 24965557 | doi = 10.1007/s00253-014-5889-y }}</ref><ref name="fbp">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.fbp.2011.12.006 |title=Pineapple wastes: A potential source for bromelain extraction |journal=Food and Bioproducts Processing |volume=90 |issue=3 |pages=385–91 |year=2012 |last1=Ketnawa |first1=Sunantha |last2=Chaiwut |first2=Phanuphong |last3=Rawdkuen |first3=Saroat | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref> The starting material is blended and pressed through a filter to obtain a [[supernatant]] liquid containing the soluble bromelain enzyme.<ref name=fbp/> Further processing includes purification and concentration of the enzyme.<ref name="pmid24965557"/> <!-- ==Other plant proteases== Other plant proteases include [[papain]] (from the [[papaya]]), [[actinidin]] (from the [[kiwi fruit]]), and [[ficin]] (from the [[ficus|fig]]). -->
==Temperature stability== After an hour at 50 °C (122 °F), 83% of the enzyme remains active, while at 40 °C (104 °F), practically 100% remains active.<ref name="Jutamongkon">{{cite journal|url=http://kasetsartjournal.ku.ac.th/kuj_files/2010/A1010081847262467.pdf|title=Effect of Temperature on the Stability of Fruit Bromelain from Smooth Cayenne Pineapple|vauthors=Jutamongkon R, Charoenrein S|journal=Kasetsart Journal: Natural Science|volume=44|pages=943–8|year=2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129015814/http://kasetsartjournal.ku.ac.th/kuj_files/2010/A1010081847262467.pdf|archivedate=2014-11-29|df=}}</ref> 8 minutes at  80 °C (176 °F) is sufficient to almost completely inactivate the enzyme.<ref name="Jutamongkon" /> The proteolytic activity of concentrated bromelain solutions remains relatively stable for at least 1 week at room temperature, with minimal inactivation by multiple freeze-thaw cycles or exposure to the digestive enzyme trypsin.<ref name=pmid15710346>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hale LP, Greer PK, Trinh CT, James CL | title = Proteinase activity and stability of natural bromelain preparations | journal = International Immunopharmacology | volume = 5 | issue = 4 | pages = 783–93 | date = April 2005 | pmid = 15710346 | doi = 10.1016/j.intimp.2004.12.007 }}</ref>
==Uses==
===Meat tenderizing and other uses=== [[File:Durkee Seasoned Meat Tenderizer.jpg|thumb|right|A jar of Durkee meat tenderizer containing bromelain.]] Along with [[papain]], bromelain is one of the most popular proteases to use for meat [[tenderizing]].<ref name="jfst">{{cite journal | vauthors = Chaurasiya RS, Sakhare PZ, Bhaskar N, Hebbar HU | title = Efficacy of reverse micellar extracted fruit bromelain in meat tenderization | journal = Journal of Food Science and Technology | volume = 52 | issue = 6 | pages = 3870–80 | date = June 2015 | pmid = 26028772 | pmc = 4444899 | doi = 10.1007/s13197-014-1454-z }}</ref> Bromelain is sold in a powdered form, which is combined with a [[marinade]], or directly sprinkled on the uncooked meat.<ref name="jfst"/>
Cooked or canned pineapple does not have a tenderizing effect, as the enzymes are [[Lability|heat-labile]] and [[Denaturation (biochemistry)|denatured]] in the cooking process. Some prepared meat products, such as meatballs and commercially available marinades, include pineapple and/or pineapple-derived ingredients.<ref name="pmid24965557"/>
Although the quantity of bromelain in a typical serving of pineapple fruit is probably not significant, specific [[extraction (chemistry)|extraction]] can yield sufficient quantities for [[home|domestic]] and industrial processing, including uses in [[baking]], [[browning (food process)|anti-browning]] of cut fruit, [[textiles]] and [[cosmetics]] manufacturing.<ref name="pmid24965557"/><ref name="jfst"/>
===Potential medical uses=== {{Main|Bromelain (pharmacology)}} {{See also|Proteases (medical and related uses)}} A concentrate of proteolytic enzymes enriched in bromelain is approved in Europe for the [[debridement]] (removal of dead tissue) of severe [[burn]] wounds under the trade name ''[[NexoBrid]]''.<ref name="nexobrid">{{cite web |url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/medicines/human/medicines/002246/human_med_001582.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac058001d124 |title=NexoBrid: concentrate of proteolytic enzymes enriched in bromelain |publisher=European Medicines Agency |date=January 7, 2013 }}</ref>
Bromelain has not been scientifically proven to be effective in treating any other diseases and it has not been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of any disorder. In the United States, the passage of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act (DSHEA, 1994) allows the sale of bromelain-containing dietary supplements even though efficacy has not been confirmed. Bromelain is a known [[allergen]].<ref name=pmid14996077>{{cite journal | vauthors = Raison-Peyron N, Roulet A, Guillot B, Guilhou JJ | title = Bromelain: an unusual cause of allergic contact cheilitis | journal = Contact Dermatitis | volume = 49 | issue = 4 | pages = 218–9 | date = October 2003 | pmid = 14996077 }}</ref>
While there have been studies which positively correlated the use of bromelain with reduction of symptom severity in osteoarthritis,<ref name=pmid12587686>{{cite journal | vauthors = Walker AF, Bundy R, Hicks SM, Middleton RW | title = Bromelain reduces mild acute knee pain and improves well-being in a dose-dependent fashion in an open study of otherwise healthy adults | journal = Phytomedicine | volume = 9 | issue = 8 | pages = 681–6 | date = December 2002 | pmid = 12587686 | doi = 10.1078/094471102321621269 }}</ref><ref name="pmid15710346"/> "[t]he majority of the studies have methodological issues that make it difficult to draw definite conclusions", as none definitively established efficacy, recommended dosage, long term safety, or adverse interaction with other medications.<ref name="ncbiReview">{{cite journal | vauthors = Brien S, Lewith G, Walker A, Hicks SM, Middleton D | title = Bromelain as a Treatment for Osteoarthritis: a Review of Clinical Studies | journal = Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 251–257 | date = December 2004 | pmid = 15841258 | pmc = 538506 | doi = 10.1093/ecam/neh035 }}</ref><ref name="nih"/>
Bromelain may be useful as an antithrombotic and anti-inflammatory in the treatment of cardiovascular disease,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Seligman B | title = Bromelain: an anti-inflammatory agent | journal = Angiology | volume = 13 | issue = 11 | pages = 508–10 | date = November 1962 | pmid = 13992714 | doi = 10.1177/000331976201301103 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/000331976201301103 }}</ref> and recent reviews on the topic suggest that it may have other beneficial properties for therapeutic treatment.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pavan R, Jain S, Kumar A | title = Properties and therapeutic application of bromelain: a review | journal = Biotechnology Research International | volume = 2012 | pages = 976203 | date = 2012 | pmid = 23304525 | pmc = 3529416 | doi = 10.1155/2012/976203 }}</ref>
Systemic enzyme therapy (consisting of combinations of proteolytic enzymes such as bromelain, trypsin, [[chymotrypsin]], and papain) has been investigated in Europe to evaluate the efficacy in breast, colorectal, and plasmacytoma cancer patients.<ref name=pmid19116226>{{cite journal | vauthors = Beuth J | title = Proteolytic enzyme therapy in evidence-based complementary oncology: fact or fiction? | journal = Integrative Cancer Therapies | volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pages = 311–6 | date = December 2008 | pmid = 19116226 | doi = 10.1177/1534735408327251 }}</ref>
Bromelain may be effective as an [[adjunct therapy]] in relieving symptoms of acute [[rhinosinusitis]] in patients not treated with [[antibiotics]].<ref name="nih">{{cite web|publisher=National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, US National Institutes of Health|url=https://nccih.nih.gov/health/bromelain|title=Bromelain|date=20 April 2016|accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref><ref name=pmid17011407>{{cite journal | vauthors = Guo R, Canter PH, Ernst E | title = Herbal medicines for the treatment of rhinosinusitis: a systematic review | journal = Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery | volume = 135 | issue = 4 | pages = 496–506 | date = October 2006 | pmid = 17011407 | doi = 10.1016/j.otohns.2006.06.1254 }}</ref> Bromelain is also claimed as a tooth plaque removal enhancer in toothpastes.<ref name="pmid24965557"/>

'''Care Opinion''', formerly Patient Opinion, is a not for profit organisation founded by Dr Paul Hodgkin in 2005 which offers patients an opportunity to offer feedback about their experience of health and social care. It is based in [[Sheffield]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Five minutes with ... the founder of Patient Opinion|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2013/dec/13/paul-hodgkin-founder-patient-opinion|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Guardian|date=13 December 2013}}</ref> There are similar organisations in Australia and Ireland. It changed its name in April 2017.
It is largely, but not exclusively, web based. Organisations which subscribe to the service pay for feedback directed to appropriate places in their organisation. There are no charges to patients. Subscribing organisations are chiefly part of the [[National Health Service]]. It is now used by over 90% of [[NHS trust]]s <ref>{{cite news|title=Choose your Best Health and Social Care Product or Service|url=http://www.digitalbydefaultnews.co.uk/2015/05/22/choose-your-best-health-and-social-care-product-or-service/|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Digital by default news|date=22 May 2015}}</ref> and is supported by the Scottish government, which encouraged health boards to engage with the website with £160,000 funding in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Patient Opinion website for rating NHS care endorsed|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-21836067|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=BBC|date=19 March 2013}}</ref>
It offer patients opportunities: *to give feedback on their health services *to easily see what others are saying For health care providers it enables them: *to hear – and respond to – patient concerns and thank-yous *to compare their ratings with others
When compared with other feedback mechanisms in the [[National Health Service|NHS]], such as the [[Friends and Family Test]] it offers much more detailed information, and the potential for dialogue, as organisations are encouraged to respond to patient stories, take action where necessary, and report back on what was done. About two thirds of stories receive a response.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Munro|first1=James|title=How the NHS should listen and act on patient complaints|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2014/nov/05/nhs-listen-act-patient-complaints|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Guardian|date=5 November 2014}}</ref> It also has the advantage of being independent.
In 2006 about 1,500 opinions and ratings were posted on the website<ref>{{cite news|last1=Munro|first1=James|title=Patient Opinion|url=http://www.sochealth.co.uk/national-health-service/democracy-involvement-and-accountability-in-health/the-new-deal-on-patient-and-public-involvement/patient-opinion/|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Socialist Health Association|date=16 January 2007}}</ref> In 2011, during the debate about the [[Health and Social Care Act 2012]] the organisation analysed the 11,000 accounts of healthcare experiences posted on the site over the previous five years focused on the most critical postings to find where patients felt the NHS needs to improve. Staff attitudes generated the biggest criticism. Only 3% perceived ‘choice of provider’ as a problem.<ref>{{cite news|title=Will Lansley listen to Patient Opinion?|url=http://leftfootforward.org/2011/03/will-andrew-lansley-listen-to-patient-opinion/|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Left Foot Forward|date=7 March 2011}}</ref> All [[NHS Scotland#Health Boards|Scottish health boards]] respond to experiences shared on the website and since it was introduced in 2011, more than 100 changes have been made to services across Scotland in response to this feedback including changes to facilities, signage and food services.<ref>{{cite news|title=More funding announced to contribute to improving the NHS|url=http://www.theedinburghreporter.co.uk/2015/04/more-funding-announced-to-contribute-to-improving-the-nhs/|accessdate=14 June 2015|publisher=Edinburgh Reporter|date=9 April 2015}}</ref> It has a system of ‘tag bubbles’ which enable searches of the data linked to particular aspects of care. This revealed that patients had high opinions of physiotherapy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Physios come out top on Patient Opinion|url=http://www.csp.org.uk/news/2016/07/22/physios-come-out-top-patient-opinion|accessdate=5 May 2017|publisher=Chartered Society of Physiotherapy|date=22 July 2016}}</ref>
An investigation by the BBC’s [[Newsnight]] programme found half of 100 reviews of the [[Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust]] on Patient Opinion had been written by staff. The trust claimed that staff were writing on behalf of vulnerable patients – such as the elderly or those with learning difficulties – who would otherwise have been unable to comment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Staff pretended to be patients in reviews of their own hospitals: NHS workers caught giving five-star ratings and positive feedback on websites |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2584854/Staff-pretended-patients-reviews-hospitals-NHS-workers-caught-giving-five-star-ratings-positive-feedback-websites.html|accessdate=16 June 2015|publisher=Daily Mail|date=20 March 2014}}</ref>
The Irish Society for Quality and Safety in Healthcare is operating a similar website which in its first five weeks received 27 detailed stories.<ref>{{cite news|title=New patient experience website ‘could save money for the health service’|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/new-patient-experience-website-could-save-money-for-the-health-service-282943.html|accessdate=16 June 2015|publisher=Irish Examiner|date=21 August 2014}}</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=February 2008}}
{{Infobox person |name = Concetta M. Tomaino |image = Drtomaino.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Dr. Concetta M. Tomaino, D.A., MT-BC, LCAT |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|7|30}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[United States|U.S]] |residence = [[New York City]], [[United States|U.S]] |nationality = |other_names = |known_for = Music Therapy |education = |employer = Institute for Music and Neurologic Function |occupation = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Walter Barrett |children = |parents = |relatives = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Dr. Concetta M. Tomaino, D.A., MT-BC, LCAT''' (born July 30, 1954), is a music therapist in the field of [[music therapy]] for individuals suffering the effects of [[stroke]] or other [[brain trauma]] or are afflicted with such degenerative neurological diseases as [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson’s]] or [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer’s]]. Tomaino is the executive director and co-founder of the [[Institute for Music and Neurologic Function]] and senior vice president for music therapy at [[CenterLight Health System]], formerly Beth Abraham Family of Health Services.
== Biography == Born and raised in [[New York City]] (the daughter of a green-grocer and what was then called a [['stay-at-home' Mom]]), Concetta Tomaino made her connection to music early, adopting the [[trumpet]] as her instrument of choice (as it remains to this day, though it is joined by the [[piano]] and [[accordion]], her main choice for therapy). The first girl in her family to attend college, Concetta enrolled at Long Island’s [[Stony Brook University]] in 1972 as a biology major, but, by her junior year, a continuing passion for music moved her to change her major to music.
Forming a synaptic-like connection between music and medicine, Concetta turned her energies to [[music therapy]], creating independent study courses because there was no music therapy program at Stony Brook. Concetta Tomaino graduated from [[Stony Brook University]] in 1976 with a Bachelor of Arts in Music Performance and minors in psychology and sciences and an abiding interest in the emerging field of music therapy.
By 1980, Concetta Tomaino had joined Beth Abraham as the only music therapist (then part of the facilities department of recreation) and began to notice patients in the dementia unit responding positively and in some cases with remarkable speed, to music. She delved deeper into the neurological underpinnings as it became clear that music therapy had more to offer patients than a mere diversion from their everyday existence.
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:sacks tomaino.jpg|thumb|Dr. Concetta M. Tomaino, world-renowned neurologist and author Dr. Oliver Sacks, and actor Dustin Hoffman at the 2006 Music Has Power Awards presented by the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function.]] -->It was at Beth Abraham in 1980 that she became acquainted with the eminent and acclaimed visiting neurologist in long-term care, Dr. [[Oliver Sacks]]. The author of a breakthrough book called “[[Awakenings]]” (later made into a movie starring [[Robert De Niro]] and [[Robin Williams]]), Tomaino found a valuable ally in Dr. Sacks when it came to championing the benefits of music therapy. Indeed, in his newest book “[[Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain]]” (Knopf, 2007) Dr. Sacks recounts case-examples of their long collaboration, adding that Connie Tomaino "has been my co-worker and adviser in all matters musical for more than twenty-five years.<sup>[1]</sup>"
In addition to her contributions with Dr. Sacks (including his 1995 volume [[An Anthropologist on Mars]]), Dr. Tomaino’s work has been featured in such other books as A Matter of Dignity by Andrew Potok, [[The Mozart Effect]] by Don Campbell, Sounds of Healing by Mitchell Gaynor, M.D. and Age Protectors (Rodale Press) and covered by television programs and networks as the BBC and such CBS News’ staples as 60 Minutes and 48 Hours.
Concetta Tomaino earned a Masters and Doctor of Arts in Music Therapy from [[New York University]] in 1998.
== Awards and affiliations == A past president of the American Association for Music Therapy, Dr. Tomaino is the recipient of numerous honors and awards, most notably the Award of Accomplishment from Music Therapists for Peace at the United Nations; the Touchstone Award from the organization Women In Music, and the Zella Bronfman Butler Award (from the UJA-Federation of New York and the J.E. and Z.B. Butler Foundation) for “outstanding work on behalf of individuals with physical, developmental or learning disabilities.<ref>[http://www.mozart-science.at/index.php?id=76&det=1&p_id=291&from_id=&L=1 Mozart & Science 2006 Speakers] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20071108191852/http://www.mozart-science.at/index.php?id=76&det=1&p_id=291&from_id=&L=1 |date=2007-11-08 }}</ref> " She was honored with the Music Has Power Award in 2004 for her outstanding contributions to the field of music therapy and for her vision, leadership, research, and service to the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function.<ref>Past Music Has Power Honorees, Institute for Music and Neurologic Function {{cite web |url=http://www.bethabe.org/Past_MHP_Honorees187.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080217103359/http://www.bethabe.org/Past_MHP_Honorees187.html |archivedate=2008-02-17 |df= }}</ref> In February 2008 America.gov, the website of the [[U.S. Department of State]]’s Bureau of International Information Programs, listed Dr. Tomaino as one of the innovators that help reshape reality.<ref>[http://amlife.america.gov/amlife/innovation/innovators.html Innovators Help Reshape Reality] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303214710/http://amlife.america.gov/amlife/innovation/innovators.html |date=2008-03-03 }}. America.gov. Retrieved on 2008-02-28.</ref>
In addition to her responsibilities as executive director of the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function and senior vice president for music therapy at Beth Abraham Family of Health Services, Dr. Tomaino is a member of the faculty of the Brookdale Center on Aging and the [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]] and serves on the visiting faculty of [[Berklee College of Music]] and [[Shenandoah University]].
Previously, she sat on the Certification Board of Music Therapists, the Journal of Music Therapy, and was a member of the advisory boards for the Center for Alternative Research at the Kessler Institute, and the International Journal of the Arts. She was also a Super Panelist participant in the GRAMMY in the Schools program and worked as an adjunct clinical supervisor for several music therapy programs in the New York area.
== Other interests == Outside of music therapy Dr. Tomaino enjoys spending time with her two daughters along with such leisurely pursuits as gardening, astronomy, painting (watercolors are the preferred medium) and performing in local symphonies and wind ensembles with her husband, music teacher and triple-threat brass player, Walter Barrett.

{{Infobox government agency | agency_name = Croatian Health Insurance Fund | type = | nativename = ''Hrvatski zavod za zdravstveno osiguranje'' | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | logo = Hzzo logo.png | logo_width = | logo_caption = | picture = | picture_width = | picture_caption = | formed = {{Start date|1993|08|21|df=y}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | agency_type = | jurisdiction = |headquarters = 3 Margaretska Street,
[[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] | coordinates = | motto = | employees = 2,211 (31 Dec 2017){{cite book|url=http://www.hzzo.hr/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Izvjesce_o_poslovanju_hzzo_01122017.pdf?b32def|title=Izvješće o poslovanju Hrvatskog zavoda za zdravstveno osiguranje za 2017. godinu|date=February 2018|language=Croatian|publisher=Croatian Health Insurance Fund|format=PDF|accessdate=1 August 2018}} | budget = [[Croatian kuna|HRK]] 23 billion (c. €3.1 billion) (2017) | minister1_name = [[Milan Kujundžić]] | minister1_pfo = [[Ministry of Health (Croatia)|Minister of Health]] | minister2_name = | deputyminister1_name = | deputyminister1_pfo = | deputyminister2_name = | deputyminister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Lucian Vukelić |chief1_position = Director | chief2_name = | chief2_position = | parent_department = | parent_agency = | child1_agency = | child2_agency = | keydocument1 = | website = {{URL|http://www.hzzo.hr}} | map = | map_width = | map_caption = | footnotes = | embed = }} The '''Croatian Health Insurance Fund''' ({{lang-hr|Hrvatski zavod za zdravstveno osiguranje}} or '''HZZO''') is a [[quasi-public]] body that administers the [[universal health care]] system in [[Croatia]]. Established in 1993, the HZZO is the country's national social [[health insurance]] fund and its primary source of health financing. In 2017, 4.24 million people received health insurance coverage through HZZO. == Organization == The HZZO is overseen by a director and a board of directors, appointed by the Croatian government on the recommendation of the [[Ministry of Health (Croatia)|Minister of Health]].{{cite journal |last1=Vončina |first1=Luca |last2=Džakula |first2=Aleksandar|last3=Mastilica |first3=Miroslav |year=2007 |title=Health care funding reforms in Croatia: a case of mistaken priorities |journal=Health Policy |volume=80 |issue=1 |pages=144–157 |url=http://medlib.mef.hr/226/1/Voncina_L_et_al_Health_care_funding_rep_226.pdf |accessdate=12 June 2013 |doi=10.1016/j.healthpol.2006.02.016}} p. 4. These directors represent the insured population, the Ministry of Health, the [[Ministry of Finance (Croatia)|Ministry of Finance]] and independent [[general practitioner]]s.Vončina, Jemiai, Merkur ''et al.'' (2006). p. 19. A central office located in the Croatian capital of [[Zagreb]], sets policies that are implemented by branch offices in each of the country's 21 [[Counties of Croatia|counties]]. All health care providers that receive public funds are required to negotiate annual contracts with the HZZO that set prices and payment plans.{{Cite journal | last1 = Vončina | first1 = L. | last2 = Strizrep | first2 = T. | last3 = Bagat | first3 = M. | last4 = Pezelj-Duliba | first4 = D. | last5 = Pavić | first5 = N. | last6 = Polašek | first6 = O. | doi = 10.3325/cmj.2012.53.66 | title = Croatian 2008–2010 health insurance reform: Hard choices toward financial sustainability and efficiency | journal = Croatian Medical Journal | volume = 53 | issue = 1 | pages = 66–76 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22351581| pmc =3284176 }} p. 3. ==Funding== Compulsory health insurance contributions form 76% of the fund's income. About a third of the population - those in employment - are liable to pay full contributions.{{cite news|title=The Health Systems and Policy Monitor|url=http://www.hspm.org/countries/croatia30062014/countrypage.aspx|accessdate=10 February 2016|work=Croatia|issue=Vol 16 no 3|publisher=European Observatory on Health Systems and Policies|date=2014}} == History == The [[Constitution of Croatia]], adopted in December 1990, declared that health care is a human right.{{cite journal |last1=Vulic |first1=Spaso |last2=Healy |first2=Judith |year=1999 |title=Health Care Systems in Transition: Croatia |publisher=European Observatory on Health Systems |url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0018/75150/E68394.pdf |accessdate=12 June 2013}} p. 6. In 1993, the HZZO was created by the [[Croatian Parliament]] in order to consolidate the fragmented and decentralized health care system which had been inherited from the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]].Vončina, Jemiai, Merkur ''et al.'' (2006). p. 13.Vončina, Džakula, Mastilica (2007). p. 2. The 1993 law recognized patient choice as a principle through a mandatory [[Payroll tax#Croatia|payroll tax]] of 15% and allowing the use of private supplementary plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.actuaries.org/EVENTS/Congresses/Cancun/associations_reports/health_reports/hr_croatia.pdf |title=Model for private health insurance in Croatia |last1=Letica |first1=Gordana |last2=Račić |first2=Tatjana |date=2002 |publisher=27th [[International Congress of Actuaries]] |accessdate=16 June 2013}} The Health Care Law of 1993 also guaranteed patients rights which includes access to information about their health, and the ability to refuse examination and treatment.{{Cite journal |last1=Bosanac|first1=Sanja Babić |last2=Borovečki |first2=Ana |last3=Fišter |first3=Kristina |year=2008 |title=Patients' rights in the Republic of Croatia – between the law and reality |journal=Medicinski Glasnik |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=37–43 |publisher=Medical Association of Zenica-Doboj Canton |url=http://www.ljkzedo.com.ba/medglasnik/vol51/M8_7.pdf |accessdate=12 June 2013}} p. 38. In July 2001, the Ministry of Health under [[Ana Stavljenić-Rukavina]] issued a policy statement entitled "The Strategy and Plan for the Reform of the Health Care System and Health Insurance of the Republic of Croatia." Noting that such factors as the [[Aging of Europe|country's aging]] and the generous benefits established since 1993 threatened the fund's sustainability,Vončina, Jemiai, Merkur ''et al.'' (2006). p. 14. the paper proposed reducing the amount of basic services that are free at the point of use, which would result in the HZZO becoming less dependent on payroll contributions.Vončina, Džakula, Mastilica (2007). pp. 7–8. In order to increase revenue, the 2002 Health Insurance Law introduced higher [[copayment]]s for hospital and specialist services. These services include [[diagnostic test]]s and [[prescription drug]]s. It also created a voluntary insurance policy that would complement the mandatory coverage each citizen received.Vončina, Jemiai, Merkur ''et al.'' (2006). p. 89. After 2002, citizens were no longer allowed to opt out of the public insurance system.{{cite journal |last1=Vončina |first1=Luca |last2=Jemiai |first2=Nadia |last3=Merkur |first3=Sherry |last4= Golna |first4= Christina |last5=Maeda |first5= Akiko |last6=Chao |first6= Shiyan |last7= Džakula |first7=Aleksandar |year=2006 |title=Croatia: Health System Review |journal=Health Systems in Transition |volume=8 |issue=7 |pages=1–108 |publisher=European Observatory on Health Systems and Policies |url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/96445/E90328.pdf |accessdate=12 June 2013}} p. 33. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *{{Official website}} {{hr icon}} [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Croatia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1993]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Croatia]] [[Category:Organizations based in Zagreb]] [[Category:Donji grad]]
